text: <@U11Q02ZKL>: it's possible
you can start VP outside the docker image (but inside vagrant)
and if you are able to ping one laptop from another
the ports in vagrant are already forwarded
and when you start the other nodes
ohh great...actually have built it outside vagrant on two individual laptops
you should set the root ip address to where you laptop is
well that should be the same
with vagrant is just easier because its is just doing node start
how outside the docker image?
./peer node start
and configuring the core.yaml file
great, i'l give it a shot..hope it works
how can I make the behave not decompose the docker containers after a test?
maybe I ve got it: one has to use the doNotDecompose tag
<@U1AU8DRQR>: yes ^^
<@U1EAX6QN5|pcen> has joined the channel
another question how can it happen that the fabric code inside Docker container of behave tests differs from the code outside (I mean in my repo)
Anybody has experience generating go code from .proto files ?
After generating the go code by running `protoc --go_out=plugins=grpc:. *.proto`, the build fails with the following error
`make peer`
<@U0YNFB22X|satheesh> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/satheesh/F1EE4P66A/make_peer_error.txt|make peer error>

cd peer; CGO_CFLAGS=" "	CGO_LDFLAGS="-lrocksdb -lstdc++ -lm -lz -lbz2 -lsnappy" go build
# github.com/hyperledger/fabric/protos

text: <@U0XQ35CDD> I seldom use Vagrant, I’ll try Vagrant this afternoon when I get to the  and let you know what I see.

<@U1AU8DRQR>: the docker images are built from the host source, so they should at least start out the same…however, if you subsequently change/pull the code I suppose its possible that you have stale docker images
<@U0YNFB22X>: not sure this will help you, but I would suggest using “make protos” as opposed to trying to run it by hand (unless I misunderstood your workflow)
<@U0YNFB22X>: are you running that command under vagrant?
<@U0KPFAZNF>: I am running it on  my local ubuntu box. And its the same in vagrant too, I had to install protobuf since its not provided in the vagrant image
<@U0KPFAZNF>: `make protos`  calls the script  `devenv/compile_protos.sh`
<@U0YNFB22X>: something sounds off…the vagrant image should indeed have protobuf
yes, understood
but you implied you were running protoc directly
Yes, it runs the same command on the suggestion from <@U0ULK2JPP>
my guess is you installed an incompatible version of protobuf
can you clarify on the problem you saw within vagrant regarding protobuf tools missing?
ok, thats fine…my only concern with running protoc vs the script/make is you’ll not get them all
<@U0YNFB22X|satheesh> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/satheesh/F1EERUNJZ/vagrant.txt|vagrant>

file.name: vagrant.txt
file.title: vagrant
file.preview:
vagrant@ubuntu-1404:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric$ devenv/compile_protos.sh 
+ protoc --go_out=plugins=grpc:/opt/gopath/src /usr/include/google/protobuf/timestamp.proto
protoc-gen-go: program not found or is not executable
--go_out: protoc-gen-go: Plugin failed with status code 1.
vagrant@ubuntu-1404:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric$
file.preview_highlight:
vagrant@ubuntu-1404:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric$ devenv/compile_protos.sh 
+ protoc --go_out=plugins=grpc:/opt/gopath/src /usr/include/google/protobuf/timestamp.proto
protoc-gen-go: program not found or is not executable
--go_out: protoc-gen-go: Plugin failed with status code 1.
vagrant@ubuntu-1404:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric$

text: try: “make protos"
<@U0KPFAZNF>: ok I will give it a go
hmm, just noticed protos is not correctly dependent on gotools
<@U0KPFAZNF>: wonder if its possible something failed during vagrant setup ?
so, as a workaround, do “make gotools protos"
<@U0ULK2JPP>: no, i think he probably did a “make clean” at one point, and I didnt correctly express the dependency in the protos target
(make clean will blow away the protoc-gen-go plugin
I see
let me try it
Do I need to destroy my vagrant before doing it ?
the correct thing is minimally that the protos target should ensure the plugin is available
<@U0YNFB22X>: nope, just “make gotools protos"
ill file an issue to correct the protos target
<@U0ULK2JPP>: to your point, its always possible vagrant didnt provision correctly too
<@U0YNFB22X>: can confirm <@U0KPFAZNF> s suspicion

vagrant@hyperledger-devenv:v0.0.10-0a467f8:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/protos$ !protoc
protoc --go_out=plugins=grpc:. *.proto
protoc-gen-go: program not found or is not executable
--go_out: protoc-gen-go: Plugin failed with status code 1.
we need to have a better way to inform/detect if vagrant didnt finish correctly, because “vagrant ssh” will still work even if the provisioner didnt make it very far at all
but that said, I think this is a more basic problem
<@U0ULK2JPP>: i guess we should review whether “make clean” should blow away the go-tools….
im a bit torn…we built them, so it seems prudent to clean them up when asked
but it could be a candidate for “make dist-clean” as opposed to the more general clean
that sounds better to me…
but that said, the real bug is I missed the proper dependency declaration
the intent of make clean is usullay “remove the dynamic stuff I created"
yeah, i think I like that too
yeah, well thats why i was torn…we _do_ create those binaries now
but, they are third party
so, I can see the argument either way
true
i think dist-clean makes sense…if you want a real clean-slate / big hammer, use dist-clean
otherwise, “make clean” will work just at the fabric level
maybe we need a make dist to be symmetric with make dist-clean ?
`make clean` did it.
we could, but not sure what it would entail
<@U0YNFB22X>: ok, so for a workaround for now, just use “make gotools protos” and I _think_ that will work
at least within vagrant
it did for me
within vagrant
it _might_ work outside of vagrant too but would be dependent on your environment
Thanks <@U0KPFAZNF> and <@U0ULK2JPP>
as an aside, I eventually plan to dissolve the compile_protos.sh script and have the makefile manage those tasks directly, so best to be in the habit of using the makefile now rather than by-hand
<@U1EEGQARJ|philippe> has joined the channel
<@U0XQ35CDD>: Just ran on my Macbook Pro with a fresh Vagrant build. The busywork stress2s fails with the issue 1091 signature:

driver:     Client 0 is subprocess 27157 with seed 4172233751
driver: Waiting (indefinitely) for subprocesses to complete
fabricLogger:ERROR: 0.0.0.0:55744 @ block 4252: Error getting transactions: missing value to go with key
fabricLogger:ERROR: Full HTTP token dump
fabricLogger:ERROR: HTTP 'ncode' = '200'
A request for a block is coming back as NULL.
Whether consensus “works” seems to be system dependent (probably related to goroutine timing?)
I have also noted that on my POWER server,  stress2s “usually” works in SMT4 and SMT8 modes, but not SMT2
Actually, as Jason points out the issue may not be with consensus but with the chain/blocks API

<@U0N1D1UAE>: If you are seeing blocks that correctly chain together (ie, contain a `PreviousBlockHash` that matches the hash of the previous block), then as much as it pains me, I believe it most likely consensus.  I'm unable to reproduce with busywork on my laptop, so although I know the logs are likely huge, if you could put them somewhere I could take a look, it would be helpful.
<@U0XPR4NP4> I’m seeing both null blocks and otherwise well-formed blocks that have no transactions. I’ll try to get traces of the well-formed blocks (assuming I have enough GSA quota)
The one's with no transactions would be of most interest to me.  The NULL ones seem less likely to be related to consensus, though obviously still need to be tracked down.
<@U0TFEHX8E>, pls help to review that <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/pull/1683>
